definition:
A bilinear form $B$ on a real or complex vector space $V$ is [*positive
definite*]{} if $B(x,x) > 0$ for all nonzero vectors $x \in V$. On the
other hand, if $B(x,x) < 0$ for all nonzero vectors $x \in V$, then we
say $B$ is [*negative definite*]{}. If $B(x,x) \ge 0$ for all vectors
$x \in V$, then we say $B$ is [*nonnegative definite*]{}. Likewise, if
$B(x,x) \le 0$ for all vectors $x \in V$, then we say $B$ is
[*nonpositive definite*]{}.

A form which is neither positive definite nor negative definite is
called [*indefinite*]{}.
